Levels.1: Minimal hypomimia, could be normal "poker face".
Levels.2: Slight but definitely abnormal diminution of facial expression.
Levels.3: Moderate hypomimia; lips parted some of the time.
Levels.4: Masked or fixed facies with severe or complete loss of facial expression; lips parted 1/4 inch or more.

TRESTFAC.Description: Tremor at rest - Face, lips, chin

Levels.1: Slight and infrequently present.
Levels.2: Mild in amplitude and persistent; or moderate in amplitude, but only intermittently present.
Levels.3: Moderate in amplitude and present most of the time.
Levels.4: Marked in amplitude and present most of the time.

RIGDNECK.Description: Rigidity - Neck (judged on passive movement of major joints with patient relaxed in sitting position; cogwheeling to be ignored)

Levels.3: Marked, but full range of motion easily achieved.
Levels.4: Severe; range of motion achieved with difficulty.

TAPSRT.Description: Finger taps - Right hand (patient taps thumb with index finger in rapid succession)

Levels.1: Mild slowing and/or reduction in amplitude.
Levels.2: Moderately impaired; definite and early fatiguing; may have occasional arrests in movement.
Levels.3: Severely impaired; frequent hesitation in initiating movements or arrests in ongoing movement.
Levels.4: Can barely perform the task.

ARISING.Description: Arising from chair (patient attempts to rise from a straight-backed chair, with arms folded across chest)

Levels.1: Slow; or may need more than one attempt.
Levels.2: Pushes self up from arms of seat.
Levels.3: Tends to fall back and may have to try more than one time, but can get up without help.
Levels.4: Unable to arise without help.

ARISINGX.Description: Arising from chair, untestable - specify reason

Levels.1: Not quite erect, slightly stooped posture; could be normal for older person.
Levels.2: Moderately stooped posture, definitely abnormal; can be slightly leaning to one side.
Levels.3: Severely stooped posture with kyphosis; can be moderately leaning to one side.
Levels.4: Marked flexion with extreme abnormality of posture.

Levels.1: Walks slowly; may shuffle with short steps, but no festination (hastening steps) or propulsion.
Levels.2: Walks with difficulty, but requires little or no assistance; may have some festination, short steps, or propulsion.
Levels.3: Severe disturbance of gait requiring assistance.
Levels.4: Cannot walk at all, even with assistance.

POSSTAB.Description: Posture stability (response to sudden, strong posterior displacement produced by pull on shoulders while patient erect with eyes open and feet slightly apart; patient is prepared)

Levels.1: Retropulsion, but recovers unaided.
Levels.2: Absence of postural response; would fall if not caught by examiner.
Levels.3: Very unstable, tends to lose balance spontaneously.
Levels.4: Unable to stand without assistance.

BRADYKIN.Description: Body bradykinesia and hypokinesia (combining slowness, hesitancy, decreased arm swing, small amplitude, and poverty of movement in general)

Levels.1: Minimal slowness, giving movement a deliberate character; could be normal for some persons; possibly reduced amplitude.
Levels.2: Mild degree of slowness and poverty of movement which is definitely abnormal. Alternatively, some reduced amplitude.
Levels.3: Moderate slowness, poverty or small amplitude of movement.
Levels.4: Marked slowness, poverty or small amplitude of movement.

BRADYKIX.Description: Body bradykinesia and hypokinesia, untestable - specify reason
